SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 1

POWER SURVEY - WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Edwin J. Macdonald
Address: 7123 16th Ave., Vancouver, BC
Birthplace: Leeds, Quebec

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1883
Where did you set up housekeeping? 20 miles from Edmonton
Where had you been living before that? Leeds, Quebec
For how many people did you prepare meals? About 5
How far was it to your nearest store? Twenty miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, rice, raisins, currants, dried apples and other groceries and always a bag of mixed candy.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Made by local mill at Butte
In what quantities did you buy it? About two hundred pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? Twenty-five miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 80¢
What other grain products did you use? Ground wheat, cornmeal, whole wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some, not a lot
How did you grind it? Ground locally with steam power
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Usually 200 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? About 50¢.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Gold Crown.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? Usually 20 lbs.

At what price? It was very cheap from 2 to 3¢ a lb.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We bought cows with us from the East.

Butter? We had our own butter.

What was the price of butter? 75¢ to 15¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, but not much.

Did you make butter? Yes, but very little.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly home cured pork.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchering our own animals.

How often did you get fresh meat? Plenty in winter, once or twice a week in summer.

How did you preserve meat? Home canned.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not for the first 25 years but after 1904 we had a butcher shop.

If so, what year was it organized? 1912.

Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Duck, chicken, and partridge.

For how long? Prairie chickens, mallards, and some went out.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Small pond caught some fish in the Vermillion River, bought some white fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Mostly fresh.

Kinds? Gold eye, pickerel, pike, white fish.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Bulk tea. At what price? Almost 35¢ lbs.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? ................. That other beverages were used? None other.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢.

If not, where from? Get some from distant neighbors.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1884. Cabbages 1884. Carrots 1884. Onions 1884.

Turnips 1884. Beets 1884.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ........................

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Both ways.

What weight? 10 lb. box. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? By bulk at time.

What was the price of prunes? 25¢ lb. box for 2.50

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? Mostly apples.

Raisins & Currants.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? .......... corn? .......... beans? .......... Saskatoons? .......... other foods? ..............................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1884.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...................

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? .....................

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? By canning.

To what extent? ...........................................................................

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.
That kind of tea did you buy? (Black Tea) At what price? (30¢ per lb.)

That kind of coffee did you buy? (Beans or ground) At what price? (25¢ per lb.)

That other beverage was used? (Tea)

That other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (Apples, apricots, peaches, pomegranates, raisins)

Preserving & Canning

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by:

peas? (Yes) corn? (Yes) beans? (Yes) tomatoes? (Yes)

other foods? (Yes)

This year did you first preserve fruits by canning?

That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

That year did you first preserve nuts by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

To what extent? (Yes)

Did you ever try another method? (No)

Did you buy baking powder? **No**. Baking soda? **Yes**.

Cream of tartar? **Not very early days**. Did you make your own baking powder? **No**.

How far was this water from your home? Half a mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel & Tank.

Water pumped by electricity all modern

Convenience on farm now!
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made our own & bought some.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... good ashes? In earlier days.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From near the Assiniboine River.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We started to burn some coal about the end of the century. In 1904 we bought a Famous Base Burner and three tons of Pennsylvania nut coal that was the best satisfaction in fuel heating I ever had in my life. But the First World War did away with the sale of nut coal so that was the end of the famous store. There has been many changes since then still going on.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Had stove.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Foundry made, brought from Quebec.

That year was it purchased? 1882-1883. Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Mostly iron but some glass.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware & China. Wooden bowl for mixing butter.

When did you first see enamel ware? About 1892.

Aluminum? 1908.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or did you make your own? Bought & used

If you made your own, did you use any special ingredients?

What kind of laundry soap did you use?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the winter last year?

Wood.

What did you get your fuel from?

Farm, store, other.

Price.

Record any changes in the use of fuel. Have you taken steps since you first started housekeeping, etc., to save money?

In what ways have you saved about the end of the century?

In 1907 we bought a farm near Bunnell and three tons of Pennsylvania coal that was delivered by the railroad. We had the first satisfaction in quiet heating I ever knew in my life. But the quiet was short lived and the cold returned with the fall of our coal so that we've been going on since then still going on.

Indoor stove.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge bread & butter, sometimes bacon & eggs.
Dinner: Sometimes soup, meat, potatoes & vegetables.
Pie but more often pudding, bread, butter & tea.
Supper: Sometimes pancakes & syrup, other times potatoes, eggs, bread & butter, fruit & tea.

1884 to 1890. Parents & grandparents & five children from two years to 10 years.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

In 1883 at a neighbor's. Two families, McCauley & Jamieson.
17 people: 2 grandfathers, 1 grandmother, 4 parents & 5 children in each family. Children's ages ranged from 1 year to 8 years.

Mrs. McCauley our hostess served the usual Christmas dinner with plenty of plum pudding.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Very little difference only now they use a can opener instead of growing it in the garden.

1. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We bought some once after 1904 but we never changed any more than we had to.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We never suffered in the early days from lack of food. We suffered five times as much hardship and mental strain in the thirties as we did in the first twenty years of pioneer life.

It's impossible to live as well in the city as in the country nearly everything has a factory taste.

We were down on the old farm for some time this summer and while they have the best of every modern convenience a large percentage of the good is home grown.

While we were there they bought home a twenty-five lb roast from the beef ring.

It would take the most of a person before to buy it here if you could find that quality of meat.
